description: Those looking to complete the CompTIA A+ 900 Series certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and details about the two exams required to pass in order to receive the certification. The certification is designed for entry level IT professionals with about a year of experience. Some of the exam objectives include hardware, networking, mobile devices, operating systems, security, and troubleshooting, making it a valuable certification to have especially for one just getting in to the IT career field with no documented experience.

00:22:11.891 --> 00:22:15.363

00:22:15.363 --> 00:22:18.640

00:22:18.640 --> 00:22:21.792

00:22:21.792 --> 00:22:24.569

The more of it I have, the more I

00:22:34.995 --> 00:22:37.105
However, as it starts to get full,

436
00:22:37.105 --> 00:22:40.635
applications might call on a location

437
00:22:40.635 --> 00:22:44.355
The virtual memory manager could then
take that information out of RAM

438
00:22:44.355 --> 00:22:46.760
that isn't currently being utilized.

00:22:46.760 --> 00:22:52.360

00:23:18.710 --> 00:23:21.290
>> Yeah, most definitely, so

00:23:26.880 --> 00:23:29.660

00:23:32.660 --> 00:23:36.719

00:23:42.041 --> 00:23:43.353

00:26:52.475 --> 00:26:56.120
Now whether there's commonality in that,
I'm not really sure.

545
00:26:56.120 --> 00:26:57.367
I don't have any statistics on it.

546
00:26:57.367 --> 00:27:03.220
But I do know that one of the most common
ones is a public only and a hybrid model.

547
00:27:03.220 --> 00:27:04.615
Those are two of the most common.

548
00:27:04.615 --> 00:27:07.860
It is the fact that
everything's in the cloud.

549
00:27:07.860 --> 00:27:11.780
Or portions are on-premise and
portions are in the cloud as well,

550
00:27:11.780 --> 00:27:12.626
the hybrid model.

551
00:27:12.626 --> 00:27:15.323
So those are a few different models
that we want you to be aware of.

552
00:27:15.323 --> 00:27:18.970
Again, remember public,
private, hybrid and community.

553
00:27:18.970 --> 00:27:21.568
Again, remember with community,
it gets a little confusing sometimes.

554
00:27:21.568 --> 00:27:23.808
Cuz you might say
community as a hybrid and

555
00:27:23.808 --> 00:27:26.117
not necessarily does it have to be hybrid.

556
00:27:26.117 --> 00:27:28.161
Everything can be in the cloud.

557
00:27:28.161 --> 00:27:30.180
Everything can be in
the cloud in a community.

558
00:27:30.180 --> 00:27:33.614
It just means you have
more than one organization

559
00:27:33.614 --> 00:27:36.810
accessing the same cloud resources.

560
00:27:36.810 --> 00:27:40.040
If Dan has company one, well,
get community out of it.

561
00:27:40.040 --> 00:27:43.041
Dan's got company one,
I've got company two.

562
00:27:43.041 --> 00:27:48.870
We can both go to AWS and
get our own cloud based services.

563
00:27:48.870 --> 00:27:52.020
But they're isolated from each other.

564
00:27:52.020 --> 00:27:56.750
Dan's information on AWS isn't allowed to
see mine, and I'm not allowed to see his.

565
00:27:56.750 --> 00:27:58.590
We're completely two separate customers.

566
00:27:58.590 --> 00:28:01.130
You don't see, that's different.

567
00:28:01.130 --> 00:28:03.580
That's one of the benefits, too,
of the cloud based solution, too,

568
00:28:03.580 --> 00:28:06.220
is that isolation between tenants.

569
00:28:06.220 --> 00:28:07.620
They call it tenant isolation.

570
00:28:08.670 --> 00:28:13.434
A community, though, is where you
have the same cloud resources.

571
00:28:13.434 --> 00:28:15.970
And two different companies
access those same resources.

572
00:28:15.970 --> 00:28:17.502
So just be careful.

573
00:28:17.502 --> 00:28:18.890
I wanna make sure that I clarify on that.

574
00:28:19.910 --> 00:28:21.380
Remember, cloud has its benefit.

575
00:28:21.380 --> 00:28:24.440
If you're a smaller company and you can't
afford the hundreds of thousands of

576
00:28:24.440 --> 00:28:29.050
dollars that it could cost to manage,
maintain, train teams to do specialized

577
00:28:30.210 --> 00:28:32.770
management of your
infrastructure on-premise.

578
00:28:32.770 --> 00:28:37.000
You can pay somebody who already has
the network, already has those resources,

579
00:28:37.000 --> 00:28:38.590
has the highly trained staff.

580
00:28:38.590 --> 00:28:41.815
They can do it for you, and
you can just pay them a service.

581
00:28:41.815 --> 00:28:43.760
So keep in mind, cloud is here.

582
00:28:43.760 --> 00:28:45.019
Cloud is where it's at.

583
00:28:45.019 --> 00:28:46.580
Cloud is here to stay.

584
00:28:46.580 --> 00:28:47.080
And in fact,

585
00:28:47.080 --> 00:28:50.840
if there's any piece of advice on any
technology within the A+ series that I

586
00:28:50.840 --> 00:28:54.770
can tell you, you really should be
studying, it better be the cloud.

587
00:28:54.770 --> 00:28:56.790
Because the cloud isn't going away.

588
00:28:56.790 --> 00:28:58.217
And it's only getting more prevalent.

589
00:28:58.217 --> 00:29:01.450
And it's getting more and
more popular as time progresses.

590
00:29:01.450 --> 00:29:04.610
>> All right, Wes, I totally agree
with everything you just said there.

591
00:29:04.610 --> 00:29:07.336
Cloud is definitely the present.

592
00:29:07.336 --> 00:29:09.300
And it definitely will
be the future as well.

593
00:29:09.300 --> 00:29:10.416
So take some time.

594
00:29:10.416 --> 00:29:13.978
Understand the difference of
the cloud types, the cloud models.

595
00:29:13.978 --> 00:29:17.180
Whether or not it's a private,
public, hybrid or community.

596
00:29:17.180 --> 00:29:18.205
Know those like the back of your hand.

597
00:29:18.205 --> 00:29:22.528
Also know the differences between
things like IaaS, SaaS, and PaaS.

598
00:29:22.528 --> 00:29:26.218
Cuz they're probably gonna hit you
with some type of question of,

599
00:29:26.218 --> 00:29:30.555
here's the setup,
what type of cloud model is that?

600
00:29:30.555 --> 00:29:34.490
And you gotta be able to,
that's platform as a service, no problem.

601
00:29:34.490 --> 00:29:35.773
Click and move on to the next one.

602
00:29:35.773 --> 00:29:37.640
So be familiar with those.

603
00:29:37.640 --> 00:29:40.790
Very good stuff, and Wes,
you did a great job presenting that.

604
00:29:40.790 --> 00:29:41.939
>> Thank you.
>> Explaining it for us,

605
00:29:41.939 --> 00:29:42.750
we appreciate that.

606
00:29:42.750 --> 00:29:44.148
We hope you guys enjoyed it out there.

607
00:29:44.148 --> 00:29:46.568
And maybe even were
a little bit entertained,

608
00:29:46.568 --> 00:29:48.620
if we could get away with that.

609
00:29:48.620 --> 00:29:50.464
But we are out of time for this episode.

610
00:29:50.464 --> 00:29:52.300
So we're gonna have to sign off.

611
00:29:52.300 --> 00:29:54.600
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

612
00:29:54.600 --> 00:29:55.360
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

613
00:29:55.360 --> 00:29:57.518
>> And we'll see you next time.

614
00:29:57.518 --> 00:30:03.525
[MUSIC]

615
00:30:03.525 --> 00:30:06.911
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

27

And it might throw you off a little bit
when we've talked about network host

28
00:01:02.166 --> 00:01:02.760
services.

29
00:01:02.760 --> 00:01:07.285
Dan and I were actually talking
discussing this before we even started

30
00:01:07.285 --> 00:01:11.357
because we've been into things
like system administration.

31
00:01:11.357 --> 00:01:12.431
I can say aluminum too,
>> Max Hedrum.

32

[LAUGH]
>> You're rubbing off on me Dan

33

that's for sure.

34

[LAUGH]
>> Aluminimum.

35

[LAUGH]
>> So you might be looking at this episode

36
00:01:20.644 --> 00:01:23.606
title and
saying what the heck are we talking about?

37
00:01:23.606 --> 00:01:27.224
And the reason I say that is because in
systems administration, in networking, we

38
00:01:27.224 --> 00:01:30.758
talk a lot about services that different
computers provide out in our networks.

39
00:01:30.758 --> 00:01:33.715
And while most of your
computers are network host,

40
00:01:33.715 --> 00:01:36.484
we gotta understand what a host means,
right?

41
00:01:36.484 --> 00:01:41.125
In the earlier days of computing,
a host really just meant something like,

42
00:01:41.125 --> 00:01:43.963
basically a centralized mainframe, right?

43
00:01:43.963 --> 00:01:47.075
It hosted all the services,
provided all the resources,

44
00:01:47.075 --> 00:01:51.282
all the storage, all the processing power
that you can have on your networks.

45
00:01:51.282 --> 00:01:53.876
Well, that really isn't
the case any more today.

46
00:01:53.876 --> 00:01:56.938
When we We talk about generically
TCPIP based networks,

47
00:01:56.938 --> 00:02:00.575
a host is really nothing more than
any self-sufficient computer,

48
00:02:00.575 --> 00:02:02.936
operating system device
that can manage and

49
00:02:02.936 --> 00:02:07.122
maintain its own networking communications
out there in the network today.

50
00:02:07.122 --> 00:02:10.116
So when we talk about network host
services what are we talking about?

51
00:02:10.116 --> 00:02:13.145
All right, I want you to think
of them about the services and

52
00:02:13.145 --> 00:02:17.344
resources that are provided to other
computers out there on the network, right?

53
00:02:17.344 --> 00:02:22.041
In past episodes we've talked a little bit
about our network architectures, right?

54
00:02:22.041 --> 00:02:24.115
Network technologies.

55
00:02:24.115 --> 00:02:25.560
We've talked about what a client is.

56
00:02:25.560 --> 00:02:27.336
We've talked about what a server is.

57
00:02:27.336 --> 00:02:29.169
We've talked about peer to
peer environments, right?

58
00:02:29.169 --> 00:02:33.828
So let's go ahead, before we dive into
the different services that we have out

59
00:02:33.828 --> 00:02:38.577
there on our networks, let's talk about
the networking models, if you will.

60
00:02:38.577 --> 00:02:42.065
Remember that we have a completely
decentralized networking model, and

61
00:02:42.065 --> 00:02:44.044
that's a peer-to-peer environment.

62
00:02:44.044 --> 00:02:47.750
They call it a peer to peer environment
because each one of the operating

63
00:02:47.750 --> 00:02:48.306
systems or

64
00:02:48.306 --> 00:02:52.508
the devices that are associated with the
operating systems out there can act like

65
00:02:52.508 --> 00:02:56.626
a client requesting a resource as well
as providing resources on the network.

66
00:02:56.626 --> 00:02:59.411
So for instance, in Microsoft Workgroup,

67
00:02:59.411 --> 00:03:04.317
that is essentially Microsoft's
implementation of a peer to peer network.

68
00:03:04.317 --> 00:03:07.085
I can have one computer that actually
has a printer connected to it.

69
00:03:07.085 --> 00:03:08.928
And that printer, if you will,

70
00:03:08.928 --> 00:03:13.316
is basically gonna be the printer that
everybody else uses on that network.

71
00:03:13.316 --> 00:03:15.767
Well, that computer is
acting kinda like a server.

72
00:03:15.767 --> 00:03:19.341
It's providing a service, a print
functionality for the rest of the network.

73
00:03:19.341 --> 00:03:21.326
While on another computer we could have,

74
00:03:21.326 --> 00:03:23.488
maybe Dan's put about
ten hard drives in it.

75
00:03:23.488 --> 00:03:27.017
So we know there's a lot of storage in
that one computer within this peer to peer

76
00:03:27.017 --> 00:03:28.412
environment, so guest what?

77
00:03:28.412 --> 00:03:32.377
That device is where we're gonna store
the majority of our business document in

78
00:03:32.377 --> 00:03:33.099
a SOHO right?

79
00:03:33.099 --> 00:03:37.004
So maybe we've got RAID array in there or
RAID1 configurations,so we've got a little

80
00:03:37.004 --> 00:03:40.183
bit of fall tolerance redundancy so
that if one of the hard drives fail.

81
00:03:40.183 --> 00:03:44.829
So you can see that those two
computers are providing resources.

82
00:03:44.829 --> 00:03:48.519
But when the computer that is actually
in that peer to peer network that is

83
00:03:48.519 --> 00:03:52.284
providing the storage for our files
needs to send something to a printer.

84
00:03:52.284 --> 00:03:54.380
Well now, it's no longer
acting like a server, right?

85
00:03:54.380 --> 00:03:58.648
It's gonna request a resource that's
provided by the other computer.

86
00:03:58.648 --> 00:04:00.640
So that's why they call them peers, right?

87
00:04:00.640 --> 00:04:04.171
And peers are in relation to
another type of topology or

88
00:04:04.171 --> 00:04:07.028
architecture called Client Server Model.

89
00:04:07.028 --> 00:04:10.034
And Client Server Models where we get
into our corporate environments, right?

90
00:04:10.034 --> 00:04:14.053
Client Server Models where we get
centralized administration rather than in

91
00:04:14.053 --> 00:04:16.103
a work group we call it decentralized.

92
00:04:16.103 --> 00:04:19.508
Cuz you have to go from computer to
computer to computer managing user

93
00:04:19.508 --> 00:04:23.330
accounts and resources, and every
computer controls it's own resources.

94
00:04:23.330 --> 00:04:27.180
User accounts and in the Client Server
Model we have centralized administration,

95
00:04:27.180 --> 00:04:29.986
cuz we can use things like
authentication servers, right?

96
00:04:29.986 --> 00:04:33.078
And when we use an authentication server
essentially what we have is a single

97
00:04:33.078 --> 00:04:34.784
server out there that's on the network.

98
00:04:34.784 --> 00:04:39.069
And what it does is it really provides
the authentication resource for

99
00:04:39.069 --> 00:04:43.074
all the other machines that are out
there on the network, right?

100
00:04:43.074 --> 00:04:46.308
So for instance, we could have
like an Active Directory domain.

101
00:04:46.308 --> 00:04:48.708
If we talked about
an Active Directory domain,

102
00:04:48.708 --> 00:04:52.188
then essentially what we mean here
is that we have one single device,

103
00:04:52.188 --> 00:04:54.952
one single computer that's
out there on the network.

104
00:04:54.952 --> 00:04:58.553
That when somebody logs in,
in fact, let me show you here,

105
00:04:58.553 --> 00:05:00.291
I got a little diagram here.

106
00:05:00.291 --> 00:05:02.213
So when somebody logs into the network,
right?

107
00:05:02.213 --> 00:05:06.054
It rather than that being checked on
the local machine, that authentication,

108
00:05:06.054 --> 00:05:09.164
it actually sends it out over
there across the network, right?

109
00:05:09.164 --> 00:05:13.016
And the user database is
stored on the server, right?

110
00:05:13.016 --> 00:05:17.153
So now we're talking, when we talk about
Client Server Model, what you have,

111
00:05:17.153 --> 00:05:18.772
you have clients, all right?

112
00:05:18.772 --> 00:05:22.932
That are, you could do most of your
day to day functionality, right?

113
00:05:22.932 --> 00:05:26.876
But they do require a certain amount of
resources or services that are provided by

114
00:05:26.876 --> 00:05:30.067
other computers out there and
that's where the server comes in.

115
00:05:30.067 --> 00:05:31.906
Keep in mind in this case the server,
right?

116
00:05:31.906 --> 00:05:35.214
Is denoted by the role or
the service that it's providing.

117
00:05:35.214 --> 00:05:38.664
In this case it happens to be
an authentication server which means when

118
00:05:38.664 --> 00:05:40.952
the client,
you log onto the client, right?

119
00:05:40.952 --> 00:05:43.492
Dan or I,
we log into our local computer here.

120
00:05:43.492 --> 00:05:47.291
Well, it really isn't the computer that
we're logging into that is providing

121
00:05:47.291 --> 00:05:48.375
the authentication.

122
00:05:48.375 --> 00:05:50.884
What it's doing is it's
calling out to the network,

123
00:05:50.884 --> 00:05:53.189
again a client requesting
resources out there.

124
00:05:53.189 --> 00:05:56.386
Saying, hey,
somebody out there on the network?

125
00:05:56.386 --> 00:06:00.084
Do you have a database that has Dan and
my username and

126
00:06:00.084 --> 00:06:03.531
passwords stored in it,
because we need to get,

127
00:06:03.531 --> 00:06:08.176
I need to see if I grant access to
this device base on that service.

128
00:06:08.176 --> 00:06:12.251
So again keep in mind that Client
Server Model means the client request

129
00:06:12.251 --> 00:06:15.371
the resources and
the server provide the resources.

130
00:06:15.371 --> 00:06:18.414
So, when we talk about network host,
kinda back to the original pointer.

131
00:06:18.414 --> 00:06:20.599
When we talk about network host service.

132
00:06:20.599 --> 00:06:24.389
All right, I want you to think about
services that we're gonna talk about,

133
00:06:24.389 --> 00:06:27.885
it's more about the servers providing
a service, providing a role,

134
00:06:27.885 --> 00:06:32.233
a functionality that's needed, typically
in things like corporate environments.

135
00:06:32.233 --> 00:06:35.919
Now it doesn't have to be a corporate
environment cuz you could have things like

136
00:06:35.919 --> 00:06:38.128
media servers out there
on a SOHO environment.

137
00:06:38.128 --> 00:06:39.954
But again due to sometime, or

138
00:06:39.954 --> 00:06:43.905
you could even have a local web
server on the local environment.

139
00:06:43.905 --> 00:06:44.936
But either way,

140
00:06:44.936 --> 00:06:49.508
keep in mind that we typically find
these in an enterprise level network.

141
00:06:49.508 --> 00:06:53.526
So in this case, an authentication server
essentially has a database, right?

142
00:06:53.526 --> 00:06:56.175
Just a little storage on the hard drive,
right?

143
00:06:56.175 --> 00:07:01.423
And it contains all of the user accounts
for every user within the network.

144
00:07:01.423 --> 00:07:05.658
And the good thing about this is,
when we say centralized management,

145
00:07:05.658 --> 00:07:10.115
it means that if we have multiple clients
out there on this type of network.

146
00:07:10.115 --> 00:07:12.578
Then a user should, in theory,

147
00:07:12.578 --> 00:07:16.691
be able to log into any one
of those client computers.

148
00:07:16.691 --> 00:07:20.580
Because, since the client computer is
just gonna hand off the authentication to

149
00:07:20.580 --> 00:07:23.954
a server that's providing that service,
we don't need to manage and

150
00:07:23.954 --> 00:07:27.060
maintain it decentralized like we
would in a peer to peer group.

151
00:07:27.060 --> 00:07:30.233
So hence a little bit about
your authentication server.

152
00:07:30.233 --> 00:07:32.833
And a little bit about where we
are going when we say services that

153
00:07:32.833 --> 00:07:33.712
are being provided.

154
00:07:33.712 --> 00:07:37.779
I want you to think of the service is
the role or functionality that is being

155
00:07:37.779 --> 00:07:42.124
performed by something that's really
nothing more than a computer, right?

156
00:07:42.124 --> 00:07:45.958
Remember, a computer is typically defined
by the operating system that is running

157
00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.985
on it, and the functionality that

21

22

talk about in this episode.

28
00:01:04.430 --> 00:01:08.000
One of the very first things that they
call out is something known as malware.

29
00:01:08.000 --> 00:01:11.600
Now when we talk about malware, what
we're talking about is really any kind of

30

if you will, that runs on your machine.

31
00:01:15.740 --> 00:01:19.480
That causes some kind of unauthorized,
undesired effect.

32
00:01:19.480 --> 00:01:23.910
Now when it comes to malware, there are
all different kinds of malware out there.

33
00:01:23.910 --> 00:01:27.070

they've talked about is something known as

34

35

understand that Spyware,

36
00:01:30.930 --> 00:01:32.610
in fact I got a little
bit of a diagram here.

37
00:01:32.610 --> 00:01:35.180
Spyware is one that gets on your computer,
and

38
00:01:35.180 --> 00:01:38.510
what it really does is it
monitors your browsing habits.

39
00:01:38.510 --> 00:01:41.610
It monitors things like your
local data store if you will,

40

monitor things like your, again,
web browsing, email clients, and.

41

they want to things like corporations for

advertisements and stuff if you will.

47
00:02:07.190 --> 00:02:10.500
But it also can happen
to be identity thieves.

48
00:02:11.500 --> 00:02:12.430
So Spyware again,

49
00:02:12.430 --> 00:02:17.280
is one that just basically monitors your
habits, your browsing habits if you will.

50
00:02:17.280 --> 00:02:21.270
Now one that's not on the list,
that's close to this is called Adware.

51
00:02:21.270 --> 00:02:23.920
And Adware is one that gets on
your machine, and when it does,

52
00:02:23.920 --> 00:02:25.661
it tries to put these pop-ups.

53
00:02:25.661 --> 00:02:30.490
Pop-ups are a really telltale

54
00:02:30.490 --> 00:02:35.460
Adware on your machine, and
it basically presents these advertisements

55
00:02:35.460 --> 00:02:39.850
along your browsing path as you're
out there across the internet.

56
00:02:39.850 --> 00:02:44.560
Now we do have other types of malware as
well, we have what are known as viruses.

57
00:02:44.560 --> 00:02:48.710
Now when a Virus is
essentially a component or

58
00:02:48.710 --> 00:02:52.420
a piece of software that needs some
kind of host, it needs to be able to

59
00:02:52.420 --> 00:02:56.760
piggy back like a file attachment if you
will or a file transfer, file download.

60
00:02:56.760 --> 00:03:01.540
If you end up visiting for

61
00:03:01.540 --> 00:03:04.650
Keep in mind, we talked about

Is gonna be non malicious.

00:03:21.630 --> 00:03:24.430
So you can get Viruses that way.

68

They can be USB-based, Email-Based or

69
00:03:28.910 --> 00:03:32.480
Keep in mind, one of the big things about

70

71
00:03:35.650 --> 00:03:39.270
And the reason I kinda stress that

73

And that's something known as a Worm.

74

And Worms are very nasty

75
00:03:45.090 --> 00:03:49.200
very nasty piece of code because
it's actually a self sufficient.

76
00:03:50.490 --> 00:03:54.100
Replicating piece of code, and
it really doesn't need a host.

77
00:03:54.100 --> 00:03:57.250
You can actually stand on the outside
of your router out there on the,

78
00:03:57.250 --> 00:04:00.836
outside of your access point in between
your network and your ISP's network,

79
00:04:00.836 --> 00:04:02.377
just waiting for a port of entry.

80
00:04:02.377 --> 00:04:05.630
And again, these can also be.

81
00:04:05.630 --> 00:04:09.700
They can be internet based,
they can consume things like USB, again,

82
00:04:09.700 --> 00:04:12.390
mail, email systems.

83
00:04:12.390 --> 00:04:15.740
Other infected systems too and
what they kind of do,

84
00:04:15.740 --> 00:04:19.120
what they really seek to do is

85
00:04:19.120 --> 00:04:25.080
For instance your disk IO, you might start

86
00:04:25.080 --> 00:04:30.250

got 99%, 100% disk utilization.

87
00:04:30.250 --> 00:04:33.890
Consuming your memory, network resources.

88
00:04:33.890 --> 00:04:38.290
In fact, we have to worry about Worms
because of the fact that they are self

89
00:04:38.290 --> 00:04:39.760
sufficient, and

90
00:04:39.760 --> 00:04:45.090
the fact that they can just maintain
their own lifecycle if you will.

91
00:04:45.090 --> 00:04:47.440
But then they're also replicating.

92
00:04:47.440 --> 00:04:50.160
They can replicate themselves,
hence the term Worm.

93
00:04:50.160 --> 00:04:52.950
You cut one Worm in half,
you end up having two Worms, and

94
00:04:52.950 --> 00:04:57.290
again each one of those worms is

95
00:04:57.290 --> 00:04:59.620
Well, Worms work the same
way in computing.

96
00:04:59.620 --> 00:05:03.990
Each one of those replicas becomes now
its own self-sufficient piece of code

97
00:05:03.990 --> 00:05:07.770
that can now, again regenerate itself.

98
00:05:07.770 --> 00:05:10.190
So definitely have to worry about Worms.

99
00:05:11.290 --> 00:05:14.230

00:30:14.100 --> 00:30:18.026

Remember that it protects information

597
00:30:28.895 --> 00:30:29.920
Now, what am I talking about?

598
00:30:29.920 --> 00:30:32.815
When I talk about coming into your

the entirety of your network.

00:21:47.210 --> 00:21:50.080

401
00:21:50.080 --> 00:21:54.350

402
00:21:54.350 --> 00:21:57.165
you have what's known as an operating
system loader, all right?

403
00:21:57.165 --> 00:22:04.759
What the boot manager, and
an operating system loader, all right?

404
00:22:04.759 --> 00:22:08.333
The boot manager, what is it,
bootmgr.exe, all right?

405
00:22:08.333 --> 00:22:12.310
It looks, and it says, what operating
system am I gonna load, all right?

406
00:22:12.310 --> 00:22:16.345
Now, if it finds a non-Windows-based
operating system, it loads a very generic

407
00:22:16.345 --> 00:22:20.341
DOS-based boot loader, and it lets the
other operating system take over the PC.

408
00:22:20.341 --> 00:22:22.450
It happens in multiboot.

409
00:22:22.450 --> 00:22:23.960
However, the other thing that it can do,

410
00:22:23.960 --> 00:22:26.880
is it can also look for
other Windows operating system loaders.

411
00:22:26.880 --> 00:22:33.360
If it's the earlier loaders, like XP,
it's gonna be looking for NTLDR, right?

412
00:22:33.360 --> 00:22:37.340
That was the XP prior to Vista,
they had a different architecture, and

413
00:22:37.340 --> 00:22:38.170
it would use NTLDR.

414
00:22:38.170 --> 00:22:41.660
Now, if that's missing,
you can get a missing NTLDR,

415
00:22:41.660 --> 00:22:44.490
then what you will have to do, is you'd
have to boot into recovery environment.

416
00:22:44.490 --> 00:22:46.700
You'd have to repair or a repair disk, and

417
00:22:46.700 --> 00:22:48.510
you would have to repair
your operating system.

418
00:22:48.510 --> 00:22:52.030
Since Vista, and all the way up to Windows
10 today, and including Windows 8.1,

419
00:22:52.030 --> 00:22:56.426
what the boot manager is looking for,
is something known as winload.exe.

420
00:22:56.426 --> 00:23:01.683
winload.exe is actually the Windows
operating system loader of today,

421
00:23:01.683 --> 00:23:04.480
in Vista, and all that really.

422
00:23:04.480 --> 00:23:06.650
All right,
now when that file gets corrupted,

423
00:23:06.650 --> 00:23:08.270
it doesn't load the operating system.

424
00:23:08.270 --> 00:23:13.071
It's also looking for
another file called NTOSKRNL.

425
00:23:13.071 --> 00:23:15.380
Well, what is that?

426
00:23:15.380 --> 00:23:16.880
That's the Windows kernel, all right?

427
00:23:16.880 --> 00:23:17.810
So see what's going on?

428
00:23:17.810 --> 00:23:19.150
We have a chain of events going on.

429
00:23:19.150 --> 00:23:23.840
We have the boot manager that
is looking for winload.exe,

430
00:23:23.840 --> 00:23:25.820
which is the operating system loader.

431
00:23:25.820 --> 00:23:29.720
And the operating system loader starts
the files, it starts the system files,

432
00:23:29.720 --> 00:23:32.140
loads system drivers, and
then looks for the kernel, and

433
00:23:32.140 --> 00:23:35.610
loads the kernel in a RAM, okay?

434
00:23:35.610 --> 00:23:38.610
Now, why did that screen that we
showed you, why it didn't load?

435
00:23:38.610 --> 00:23:42.560
If it didn't find the operating system,
what the heck are we seeing there?

436
00:23:42.560 --> 00:23:47.240
Well, understand that every time
your computer boots, all right?

437
00:23:48.370 --> 00:23:50.378
When your computer boots,

438
00:23:50.378 --> 00:23:55.803
it sets a little flag to automatically
failover to recovery, all right?

439
00:23:55.803 --> 00:23:58.442
It's called automatic recovery failover,
all right?

440
00:23:58.442 --> 00:24:03.839
And it sets a little flag, and it lets
the bootmgr know don't load WinLoad.

441
00:24:03.839 --> 00:24:05.706
Don't load the operating system loader.

442
00:24:05.706 --> 00:24:07.940
Something went wrong.

443
00:24:07.940 --> 00:24:09.480
Load the recovery environment.

444
00:24:09.480 --> 00:24:11.640
Load the pre-installation environment.

445
00:24:11.640 --> 00:24:14.220
So that you can fix it if you need to.

446
00:24:14.220 --> 00:24:18.430
Now this happens every time you
boot your machine, every time,

447
00:24:18.430 --> 00:24:19.440
whether something's wrong or not.

448
00:24:20.480 --> 00:24:23.040
As it goes through the boot process,

449
00:24:23.040 --> 00:24:27.210
if it finds that there's nothing wrong,
it loads WinLoad.

450
00:24:27.210 --> 00:24:29.090
It still has that flag set though.

451
00:24:29.090 --> 00:24:32.110
Keep in mind that recovery
environment flag is set.

452
00:24:32.110 --> 00:24:36.395
WinLoad loads, starts the file system,
initializes the file systems,

453
00:24:36.395 --> 00:24:38.065
starts the system drivers.

454
00:24:38.065 --> 00:24:41.378
And then goes to the NTOSKRNL and
loads the kernel, and

455
00:24:41.378 --> 00:24:44.450
the kernel starts to
come online in bootstrap.

456
00:24:44.450 --> 00:24:48.110
Then you're presented with a logon screen.

457
00:24:48.110 --> 00:24:52.570
When you log onto your machine,
the boot loader,

458
00:24:52.570 --> 00:24:56.250
the boot MGR,
removes the recovery flag, removes it.

00:24:57.630 --> 00:25:01.890

00:25:01.890 --> 00:25:04.150

So at a certain point the boot

00:25:22.490 --> 00:25:25.820

00:25:25.820 --> 00:25:26.870
>> It's a fail safe, right?

00:25:29.350 --> 00:25:33.750
So again, as a real quick recap,
we boot process starts,

473
00:25:40.200 --> 00:25:43.140
Once you normally boot
the operating system and

00:25:43.140 --> 00:25:47.030

00:25:49.290 --> 00:25:51.690

00:25:51.690 --> 00:25:52.980

00:25:54.140 --> 00:25:57.690
Now when you restart your computer,

479
00:25:57.690 --> 00:25:58.920

machines running.

On the internal side, right?

00:28:00.067 --> 00:28:01.970

556

558
00:28:06.593 --> 00:28:09.337
Zach, well, you only have two eyes,

00:28:12.400 --> 00:28:14.430

563

Or maybe somebody's been
through that same situation and

566
00:28:28.750 --> 00:28:31.330

567
00:28:31.330 --> 00:28:33.970
So definitely conduct your
research as well, right?

568
00:28:33.970 --> 00:28:36.200
So if it's a hardware,
is it a driver issue?

569
00:28:36.200 --> 00:28:39.830
Don't overlook the fact that it
could be just a driver issue.

570
00:28:39.830 --> 00:28:42.600
Don't overlook that if it's a hardware
issue, is it a connection issue?

571
00:28:42.600 --> 00:28:43.840
Simple connection, the hard drive,

572
00:28:43.840 --> 00:28:46.970
computer isn't booting up,
what did you do recently?

573
00:28:46.970 --> 00:28:48.900
Well, I put in another drive.

574
00:28:48.900 --> 00:28:51.980
Really?
Did you hook up the power cable?

575
00:28:51.980 --> 00:28:53.150
Did you hook up the data cable?

576
00:28:53.150 --> 00:28:58.011
Did you turn the interface on the
motherboard on in the BIOS or the UEFI?

577
00:28:58.011 --> 00:28:58.929
I don't know.

578
00:28:58.929 --> 00:29:01.540
But at least we should question it, right?

579
00:29:01.540 --> 00:29:02.550
Software.

580
00:29:02.550 --> 00:29:06.225
Again, goes back to
the user experience level.

581
00:29:06.225 --> 00:29:08.290
And again,
this is not cutting anybody down.

582
00:29:08.290 --> 00:29:11.250
It's just the fact of the matter that
somebody might not be able to send

583
00:29:11.250 --> 00:29:13.640

to click the Send button.

584
00:29:15.300 --> 00:29:17.410
And again, not talking down to anybody.

585
00:29:17.410 --> 00:29:19.500
You have to be willing to
support your end users, and

586
00:29:19.500 --> 00:29:24.010
you have to meet them at
their experience level.

587
00:29:24.010 --> 00:29:26.310
And that doesn't put
yourself on a pedestal.

588
00:29:26.310 --> 00:29:28.636
The moment you put yourself on a pedestal,
trust me,

589
00:29:28.636 --> 00:29:30.994
you can be knocked off of
it really quickly [LAUGH].

590
00:29:30.994 --> 00:29:31.511
>> Yeah.

591
00:29:31.511 --> 00:29:33.630
>> Just by circumstance alone.

592
00:29:33.630 --> 00:29:36.050
Configuration, if it's a software issue.

593
00:29:36.050 --> 00:29:40.460
Yes, malware, could have been something,
could have been an installation, right?

594
00:29:40.460 --> 00:29:41.900
Could be a permissions issue.

595
00:29:43.280 --> 00:29:46.214
But remember, what we're doing
is we're looking at the cause.

596
00:29:46.214 --> 00:29:50.170
And the cause usually has
some kind of problem.

597
00:29:51.490 --> 00:29:54.610
We need to know what
the underlying root cause is.

598
00:29:54.610 --> 00:29:58.270
The symptoms, or
the problem is the computer isn't booting.

599
00:29:58.270 --> 00:29:59.802
That's the problem, that's not the cause.

600
00:29:59.802 --> 00:30:02.090
The cause could be the fact
that you don't have power.

601
00:30:02.090 --> 00:30:06.830
Could be the fact that you
have over-heating, all right?

602
00:30:06.830 --> 00:30:08.970
Malware, malware's a big one.

603
00:30:08.970 --> 00:30:12.510
Malware's the cause, but
we also have to determine,

604
00:30:12.510 --> 00:30:16.720

shouldn't be doing on their machine

605
00:30:16.720 --> 00:30:18.830

606
00:30:18.830 --> 00:30:22.070
So there are other things that
we have to think about as well.

607

Now, I know, Zach, we only got through
a couple of these bullet points, but

608
00:30:25.320 --> 00:30:28.230
it does look like we are running to
the end, cuz, well, I talk a lot.

>> [LAUGH]
>> But at the same time, we wanna.

Which hopefully isn't a problem

it does look like we're gonna have
to go into a part two on this one.

612
00:30:35.772 --> 00:30:39.044
>> Well, and that's okay,
because we are troubleshooting.

613
00:30:39.044 --> 00:30:42.353
CompTIA's troubleshooting theory,

614
00:30:42.353 --> 00:30:46.402
This has been part one as we

WEBVTT

1

7

8

9

There was a part one, and

11

12
00:00:33.930 --> 00:00:35.460
Wes, good to see you again, sir.

13
00:00:35.460 --> 00:00:36.050
>> Hey, man.

14

15

>> Tell us things, tell us.

16
00:00:37.902 --> 00:00:38.671
>> [LAUGH] That's right, that's right.

17
00:00:38.671 --> 00:00:39.929
You know what we're gonna talk about?

18
00:00:39.929 --> 00:00:41.512
We're going to talk about
this troubleshooting theory.

19
00:00:41.512 --> 00:00:44.700
That's right, remember,
we are putting method to the madness.

20
00:00:44.700 --> 00:00:46.730
Now speaking of madness,
in the first part,

21
00:00:46.730 --> 00:00:48.090

22

23

We were talking about,
really just the first two steps.

24
00:00:52.020 --> 00:00:54.500
In fact,
I wanna take a look at a diagram here,

25
00:00:54.500 --> 00:00:57.170
because these are the steps that we have.

26
00:00:57.170 --> 00:00:59.850
Remember, we were talking
about identifying a problem,

27
00:00:59.850 --> 00:01:03.490
establishing a theory of probable cause,
just a theory to determine the cause,

28
00:01:03.490 --> 00:01:05.220
establish a plan, if I could say that,

29
00:01:05.220 --> 00:01:09.540
establish a plan of action to resolve
the problem and implement a solution.

30
00:01:09.540 --> 00:01:12.840
Verify full system functionality,
and if applicable,

31
00:01:12.840 --> 00:01:17.820
implement preventive measures and document
your findings, actions and outcomes.

32
00:01:17.820 --> 00:01:20.410
Well, in the first part,
we really only got to the first two steps.

33
00:01:20.410 --> 00:01:24.350
We got through identifying the problem and
establishing the theory of probable cause.

34
00:01:24.350 --> 00:01:28.530
As just a really quick recap,
if you're not aware, go back and

35
00:01:28.530 --> 00:01:29.870
watch that first one.

36
00:01:29.870 --> 00:01:31.520
Come back here and
we'll see in the second one.

37
00:01:31.520 --> 00:01:36.230
Keep in mind, don't assume anything, and
always question the obvious, right, when

38
00:01:36.230 --> 00:01:40.530

establishing a theory of probable cause.

39
00:01:40.530 --> 00:01:44.890
Now let's go ahead and one more time let's
take a look at the next one here, right?

40
00:01:44.890 --> 00:01:48.655
We got test the theory
to determine the cause.

41

All right, now there are a couple of
things that we need to think about

42
00:01:52.160 --> 00:01:56.770

to determine the cause, all right?

43

Here's where you might
start making changes.

44
00:01:59.410 --> 00:02:03.450
You could potentially make changes to
a system that could cause a problem.

45
00:02:03.450 --> 00:02:08.390
So if you haven't done it up until this
point, I mentioned it in the first step,

46
00:02:08.390 --> 00:02:10.310
but if you haven't done
it up until this point,

47
00:02:10.310 --> 00:02:13.330
you need to take your backups, all right?

48
00:02:13.330 --> 00:02:18.297
Now one of the things you have
to keep in mind is that if you

49
00:02:18.297 --> 00:02:21.376
are going to take backups, okay?

50
00:02:21.376 --> 00:02:23.920
I've kinda put these in a couple
different locations, right?

51
00:02:23.920 --> 00:02:26.737
If we're gonna implement a plan of action,
right,

52
00:02:26.737 --> 00:02:29.490
implement a plan of action
to resolve the problem,

53
00:02:29.490 --> 00:02:34.320
which is the next step after that, you
could put those there as well, all right?

54
00:02:34.320 --> 00:02:38.006
If you're gonna start testing theories
to determine your causes, right,

55
00:02:38.006 --> 00:02:41.760
if you believe that it's
an overheating issue, right?

56
00:02:41.760 --> 00:02:45.670
Again, you could cause damage to
the system and that could corrupt data.

57
00:02:45.670 --> 00:02:49.140
So at this point, I'll say that
I'm probably going to say that

58
00:02:49.140 --> 00:02:51.620
you should determine about
your backups here, right,

59
00:02:51.620 --> 00:02:54.130
rather than putting them in step four,

60
00:02:54.130 --> 00:02:56.330
If you check the notes out
that we put up on the website,

61

you might see it in step four.

62
00:02:57.620 --> 00:03:02.330
Again, because of the fact that it's
not until you start making changes, if

63
00:03:02.330 --> 00:03:06.950
you're testing a theory to determine the
cause and that implies that you're gonna

64
00:03:06.950 --> 00:03:11.390
start making some changes, you definitely
have to start your backup process now.

65
00:03:11.390 --> 00:03:14.740
You need to determine,
first of all, are backups present?

66
00:03:14.740 --> 00:03:17.150
All right, maybe I already have backups.

67
00:03:17.150 --> 00:03:20.760
If you already have backups and you have
a backup system running, then you're good.

68
00:03:20.760 --> 00:03:22.390
You can start testing theories.

69
00:03:22.390 --> 00:03:26.694
You also have to understand,
can the backups even be taken, all right?

70
00:03:26.694 --> 00:03:27.960
And here's what I mean by that.

71
00:03:27.960 --> 00:03:30.132
If you have a hard drive that's failing,
all right,

72
00:03:30.132 --> 00:03:32.550
you might not wanna reboot your system.

73
00:03:32.550 --> 00:03:36.407
Right, there are times where I've seen
hard drives that while the system was

74
00:03:36.407 --> 00:03:38.440
still powered on would function.

75
00:03:38.440 --> 00:03:42.570
The moment you restarted
the machine to try to test things,

76
00:03:42.570 --> 00:03:44.866
the hard drive never initiated again.

77
00:03:44.866 --> 00:03:47.230
And now it's to the point where you
have to take it out of the machine,

78
00:03:47.230 --> 00:03:51.400
you have to, if it's important enough, you
have to take it to some kind of company

79
00:03:51.400 --> 00:03:53.040
and they have to perform data recovery.

80
00:03:53.040 --> 00:03:57.165
Understand that data recovery
solutions can be very expensive, and

81
00:03:57.165 --> 00:04:02.100
when we have hard drives today
that are terabytes, all right,

82
00:04:02.100 --> 00:04:05.938
you can get into several hundreds of
dollars very, very quickly, okay?

83
00:04:05.938 --> 00:04:10.528
So all right, that's why I say if you're
testing a theory to determine the cause

84
00:04:10.528 --> 00:04:14.915
here in the third step and that implies
making some kind of change to the system

85
00:04:14.915 --> 00:04:19.055
or modification in any way,
your backup should be running here, okay?

86
00:04:19.055 --> 00:04:21.996
All right,
you might have to determine too, and

87
00:04:21.996 --> 00:04:26.640
again I know I'm kinda sticking
on backups real quick, okay?

88
00:04:26.640 --> 00:04:31.230
But backups, if you have to take backups,

89
00:04:31.230 --> 00:04:34.850
is data recovery gonna be
required by a third party?

90
00:04:34.850 --> 00:04:38.610
Is that's something that's
even provided by your company

91
00:04:38.610 --> 00:04:41.830
as an A+ help desk technician?

92
00:04:41.830 --> 00:04:43.410
Right, maybe that's something
you can do internally.

93
00:04:43.410 --> 00:04:45.430
You could say, well,
hey we're gonna have to do such and such.

94
00:04:45.430 --> 00:04:48.050
I'm gonna make a potential change
here that could cause a problem.

95
00:04:48.050 --> 00:04:49.770
We might need to back up your data.

96
00:04:49.770 --> 00:04:52.640
However, we also have
a data recovery solution or

97
00:04:52.640 --> 00:04:55.310
you might have to recommend one, okay?

98
00:04:55.310 --> 00:04:56.770
Now once the theory is confirmed,

99
00:04:56.770 --> 00:04:59.750
determine the next steps to resolve
whatever the problem might be.

100
00:04:59.750 --> 00:05:05.155
If I figure out, hey, it is,
right, I get on that third

101
00:05:05.155 --> 00:05:11.145
step if I determine that it is
some kind of overheating issue.

102
00:05:11.145 --> 00:05:16.060
Well, then I have to make sure
what the next steps might be.

103
00:05:16.060 --> 00:05:18.810
However, keep in mind if we're testing
the theory and it's not confirmed,

104
00:05:18.810 --> 00:05:22.410
then what we're gonna have to do is we're
gonna have to reestablish a new theory.

105
00:05:22.410 --> 00:05:24.540
And that's the other thing that
we also wanna keep in mind.

106
00:05:24.540 --> 00:05:27.840
When we talk about establishing
a theory of probable cause,

107
00:05:27.840 --> 00:05:30.140
back in the second step,

108
00:05:30.140 --> 00:05:35.260
we did that in the first part of this
little series that we got going on here.

109
00:05:35.260 --> 00:05:39.080
Make sure that you establish
multiple points of probable cause.

110
00:05:39.080 --> 00:05:40.550
Don't just stop with one.

111
00:05:40.550 --> 00:05:41.310
And why do I say that?

112
00:05:41.310 --> 00:05:42.250
Cuz if you stop with one,

113
00:05:42.250 --> 00:05:47.200
you're gonna have to go back to
the drawing board more and more often.

114
00:05:47.200 --> 00:05:49.100
So come to the table prepared.

115
00:05:49.100 --> 00:05:51.990
Come to the table with more
than one potential cause so

116
00:05:51.990 --> 00:05:56.650
that you can systematically work through
this, you have a systematic approach.

117
00:05:56.650 --> 00:05:58.700
You could work through each one,
all right?

118
00:05:58.700 --> 00:06:01.487
But if you work through each one and
again, the theory is not confirmed,

119
00:06:01.487 --> 00:06:02.823
just re-establish a new theory.

120
00:06:02.823 --> 00:06:06.840
Or maybe it's not within your wheelhouse.

121
00:06:06.840 --> 00:06:08.770
If it's not within your wheelhouse,
ladies and

122
00:06:08.770 --> 00:06:12.240
gentlemen, it is not a bad
thing to say I don't know.

123
00:06:13.600 --> 00:06:17.150
What is a bad thing is to say I know and
then not know, cuz you're held accountable

124
00:06:17.150 --> 00:06:20.110
for what you say you know,
whether you do or you don't, all right?

125
00:06:20.110 --> 00:06:21.180
And that's one of the things.

126
00:06:21.180 --> 00:06:23.440
Let me give you an example.

127
00:06:23.440 --> 00:06:26.890
If it's an electrical issue, right, if
it's an electrical issue within the power

128
00:06:26.890 --> 00:06:31.100
supply, I know enough to know that I
shouldn't be opening a power supply,

129
00:06:31.100 --> 00:06:34.520
because they have capacitors in them that
can retain enough amperage whether they're

130
00:06:34.520 --> 00:06:37.460
working or
not to kill you when you touch them.

131
00:06:37.460 --> 00:06:39.330
Stop your heart instantly.

132
00:06:39.330 --> 00:06:42.830
All right, so what I recognize is that
if it's a power supply problem, yeah,

133
00:06:42.830 --> 00:06:47.040
I can fix it by replacing
the power supply, not opening it.

134
00:06:47.040 --> 00:06:51.790
But if it happens to be the electrical
outlet on the wall that's the problem,

135
00:06:51.790 --> 00:06:55.850
I also have enough knowledge to know that
I need to escalate that to an electrical

136
00:06:55.850 --> 00:06:57.330
engineer, an electrician.

137
00:06:57.330 --> 00:07:00.308
Somebody that has the know how to fix
that outlet on the wall, not Wes.

138

[LAUGH]
>> And it's funny you're actually

00:07:01.833 --> 00:07:04.325

140
00:07:04.325 --> 00:07:05.259
I found that out this morning.

141
00:07:05.259 --> 00:07:06.113
[LAUGH]
>> That's really,

142
00:07:06.113 --> 00:07:06.910
that's funny, that's funny [LAUGH].

143
00:07:06.910 --> 00:07:07.780
And I didn't even know that.

144
00:07:07.780 --> 00:07:12.230
So the socket that we're theoretically,
in reality pointing to,

145
00:07:12.230 --> 00:07:13.470

00:07:13.470 --> 00:07:16.341
